snippet: The war is setting off a contagious sectarian conflict in Iraq and Lebanon, rekindling long-simmering tensions.
abstract: Syrian civil war is setting off contagious sectarian conflicts in Iraq and Lebanon, rekindling long-simmering tensions between Sunnis and Shiites; renewed sectarian killing has brought highest death toll in Iraq in five years; in Lebanon, clashes have worsened between opposing sects in northern city of Tripoli; more than 80,000 have died from fighting in Syria.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO, ANNE BARNARD and DURAID ADNAN
byline.contributor: Tim Arango and Duraid Adnan reported from Baghdad, and Anne Barnard from Damascus, Syria, and Beirut, Lebanon. Reporting was contributed by employees of The New York Times from Hilla, Iraq, and Najaf, Iraq, and by Hania Mourtada and Hwaida Saad from Beirut.

lead_paragraph: The war is setting off a contagious sectarian conflict in Iraq and Lebanon, rekindling long-simmering tensions.

headline.seo: Sunni-Shiite Violence Flares in Mideast in Wake of Syria War
headline.main: As Syrians Fight, Sectarian Strife Infects Mideast
headline.print_headline: As Syrians Fight, Sectarian Strife Infects Mideast

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
